div1.p: This document discusses the diagnosis and treatment of yellow fever in Cuba.

div1.head: Memorandum from R.E.L. Michie, August 18, 1900
div1.p:
Paragraph 2, Circular No. 1, series 1900, Headquarters
Department of the Province of Havana and Pinar del Rio,
is, upon the recommendation of the Chief Surgeon, hereby
amended and republished as follows, for the information
and guidance of all concerned:

With reference to the early diagnosis of cases of yellow
fever, two symptoms should be particularly watched for in
all cases:
1. The appearance of albumen in the urine.

2. A gradual fall in the pulse-rate while the tempera-
ture remains stationary, or is rising; or a dispro-
portionate slowness of the pulse as compared with
the temperature (Faget's law). To this end, the
urine will be tested daily, and the temperature
and pulse taken three times a day, for the first
five days of fever.

An accurate record in ink will be kept of these observa-
tions on temperature charts, and these charts will be care-
fully preserved and forwarded to the office of the Chief
Surgeon with the monthly Report of Sick and Wounded.

Attention is invited particularly to the following para-
graph of Circular No. 9, 1899, Headquarters Division of
Cuba, publishing certain sanitary suggestions of the Surgeon
General:

Every case of fever should receive prompt attention. If albumen is
found in the urine of a patient with fever it should be considered suspicious
(of yellow fever), and he should be placed in an isolated tent. The dis-
charges of patients with fever should always be disinfected at once with a
solution of carbolic acid (5 per cent), or of chloride of lime (6 ounces to a
gallon of water), or with milk of lime made fresh from quicklime.
div1.closer:
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE: R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General. Headquarters Dept.
Havana and Pinar del Rio
QUEMADOS CUBA
OFFICIAL
